2022-08-14

Some KEMs and Some Proofs

  • #cryptography
  • #foundations
  • #kems

In this post, I'd like to provide a technical introduction to key encapsulation mechanisms (KEMs), with a focus on proving the security of various constructions.

A key encapsulation mechanism is like a public key encryption scheme, tailored to the specific use case of sending a key to the other party. This can be used to establish shared key between two parties. One of them runs the KEM, getting a shared key and a ciphertext, and then sends that ciphertext to the other person. That person can unwrap the ciphertext to recover the shared key. From that point on, the parties can use that shared key to communicate privately.

In this way, you can think of KEMs as a generalization of key exchanges, which don't have to be symmetric. In fact, you can use a key exchange to construct a KEM, as we'll see later.

In this post, we'll go over:

  • How to define KEMs.
  • How to capture the security of KEMs with games.
  • How these notions of security compare with other variations.
  • How to construct a secure KEM from RSA.
  • How to construct a secure KEM using Elliptic Curves.

There are other important topics around KEMs that I'd also like to touch upon, but this sample is already quite a hefty serving if you include all of the proofs; those will have to wait for a future post.

Background

For a high level overview of KEMs, I'd recommend Neil Madden's post on the subject.

This post is more focused on the technical side of things, and on provable security. I'll be using state separable proofs pervasively throughout this post, so I'd recommend reading my post on the subject if you'd like to get up to speed.

Defining KEMs

To begin, let's formally define what a KEM is.

A key encapsulation mechanism (KEM), is a scheme similar to public key encryption. This scheme consists of three algorithms:

Gen:()→(SK,PK)Encap:PK→(K,C)Decap:(SK,C)→K\begin{aligned} \text{Gen} &: () \to (\bold{SK}, \bold{PK})\cr \text{Encap} &: \bold{PK} \to (\bold{K}, \bold{C})\cr \text{Decap} &: (\bold{SK}, \bold{C}) \to \bold{K} \end{aligned}GenEncapDecap​:()→(SK,PK):PK→(K,C):(SK,C)→K​

The first algorithm, Gen\text{Gen}Gen, creates a new key pair, consisting of a private key, and its corresponding public key.

The second algorithm, Encap\text{Encap}Encap, takes in a public key, for the recipient, and returns a symmetric key and an encapsulation (also called a ciphertext).

With Decap\text{Decap}Decap, a recipient can use their private key to extract a symmetric key from the ciphertext.

This scheme also needs to satisfy some notion of correctness. Intuitively, decapsulating should return the same key that was encapsulated.

More formally, the following procedure must always succeed:

(sk,pk)←Gen()(kS,c)←Encap(pk)kR←Decap(sk,c)kS=?kR\begin{aligned} &(\text{sk}, \text{pk}) \gets \text{Gen}()\cr &(k_S, c) \gets \text{Encap}(\text{pk})\cr &k_R \gets \text{Decap}(\text{sk}, c)\cr &k_S \stackrel{?}{=} k_R \end{aligned}​(sk,pk)←Gen()(kS​,c)←Encap(pk)kR​←Decap(sk,c)kS​=?kR​​

No matter what key pair comes out of Gen\text{Gen}Gen, encapsulating and then decapsulating must return the same key. If this didn't hold, your KEM wouldn't be very useful for establishing a shared key between two parties, or for public key encryption, which are two of the main use cases for KEMs.

IND\text{IND}IND Security

Naturally, having a correct scheme is easy if you don't care about security. The usual notion of security is similar to that of public key encryption. The basic idea is that you shouldn't be able to tell whether or not a specific key is hidden inside of the ciphertext. In particular, you shouldn't be able to distinguish between receiving a random key, and receiving the key inside of a ciphertext.

We formalize this as a pair of games, in the state separable style:

INDb (sk,pk)←RGen()GetPk():‾ return pkChallenge():‾ (k0,c)←Encap(pk) k1←RK return (kb,c)\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\text{IND}_b$ }\cr \cr &(\text{sk}, \text{pk}) \xleftarrow{R} \text{Gen}()\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{GetPk}():}\cr &\ \texttt{return } \text{pk} \cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{Challenge}():}\cr &\ (k_0, c) \gets \text{Encap}(\text{pk}) \cr &\ k_1 \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\ \texttt{return } (k_b, c) \cr \end{aligned} }​INDb​ ​(sk,pk)R​Gen()GetPk():​ return pkChallenge():​ (k0​,c)←Encap(pk) k1​R​K return (kb​,c)​​

In one version of the game, we get the key inside the encapsulation, and in the other version of the game, we get a completely random key. An adversary should not be able to distinguish between the two games.

This means that the adversary can't learn any information about the key from the ciphertext.

[!note] Note: In this variant, you can query the challenge multiple times. This is equivalent to only being able to query once, although the security gets worse as a linear function of the number of queries you do. For simplicity, I'll stick with the multi-query variants for the rest of this post.

This variant of security can also be referred to as IND-CPA\text{IND-CPA}IND-CPA. This is because the adversary is able to create encapsulations themselves, because they know the public key. This kind of query is a chosen plaintext, hence the chosen plaintext attack (CPA) in the name.

With symmetric encryption, on the other hand, you need to have a secret key to even encrypt data, so the CPA\text{CPA}CPA capability is a meaningful distinction.

IND-CCA\text{IND-CCA}IND-CCA Security

An even stronger variant of security also allows the adversary to make decapsulation queries on ciphertexts of their choice. We call these chosen ciphertext attacks (CCA). This models situations where we might know the keys inside certain ciphertexts. While in practice these leakages could be quite limited, having a more expansive model of security covers many more situations, and we can construct schemes which satisfy this general model.

We model this with a pair of games, like before:

IND-CCAb seen←∅(sk,pk)←RGen()GetPk():‾ return pkChallenge():‾ (k0,c)←Encap(pk) k1←RK seen←seen∪{c} return (kb,c)Decap(c):‾ assert c∉seen return Decap(sk,c)\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\text{IND-CCA}_b$ }\cr \cr &\text{seen} \gets \emptyset\cr &(\text{sk}, \text{pk}) \xleftarrow{R} \text{Gen}()\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{GetPk}():}\cr &\ \texttt{return } \text{pk} \cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{Challenge}():}\cr &\ (k_0, c) \gets \text{Encap}(\text{pk}) \cr &\ k_1 \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\ \text{seen} \gets \text{seen} \cup \{c\}\cr &\ \texttt{return } (k_b, c) \cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{Decap}(c):}\cr &\ \texttt{assert } c \notin \text{seen}\cr &\ \texttt{return } \text{Decap}(\text{sk}, c) \cr \end{aligned} }​IND-CCAb​ ​seen←∅(sk,pk)R​Gen()GetPk():​ return pkChallenge():​ (k0​,c)←Encap(pk) k1​R​K seen←seen∪{c} return (kb​,c)Decap(c):​ assert c∈/seen return Decap(sk,c)​​

This is the same as the previous IND\text{IND}IND game, except that we now have the ability to make decapsulation queries. In order to make the game not trivially easy to win, we keep track of which challenge ciphertexts have been produced, and refuse decapsulation queries for that set. Otherwise, you could ask for the decapsulation for a ciphertext you saw earlier, and compare the result with the key you received before.

Equivalence with Other Definitions

[!note] Note: You can skip this section. It's mainly concerned with resolving a small discrepancy in definitions between this post and the broader literature.

In the games we've seen so far, the adversary only sees one of the keys. We can also model a situation where the adversary sees both of the keys:

IND-Both-CCAb seen←∅(sk,pk)←RGen()GetPk():‾ return pkChallenge():‾ (kb,c)←Encap(pk) k_(1−b)←RK seen←seen∪{c} return (k0,k1,c)Decap(c):‾ assert c∉seen return Decap(sk,c)\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\text{IND-Both-CCA}_b$ }\cr \cr &\text{seen} \gets \emptyset\cr &(\text{sk}, \text{pk}) \xleftarrow{R} \text{Gen}()\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{GetPk}():}\cr &\ \texttt{return } \text{pk} \cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{Challenge}():}\cr &\ (k_b, c) \gets \text{Encap}(\text{pk}) \cr &\ k\_{(1 - b)} \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K} \cr &\ \text{seen} \gets \text{seen} \cup \{c\}\cr &\ \texttt{return } (k_0, k_1, c) \cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{Decap}(c):}\cr &\ \texttt{assert } c \notin \text{seen}\cr &\ \texttt{return } \text{Decap}(\text{sk}, c) \cr \end{aligned} }​IND-Both-CCAb​ ​seen←∅(sk,pk)R​Gen()GetPk():​ return pkChallenge():​ (kb​,c)←Encap(pk) k_(1−b)R​K seen←seen∪{c} return (k0​,k1​,c)Decap(c):​ assert c∈/seen return Decap(sk,c)​​

Instead of giving them one of the keys like before, we give them both, but we swap their order. The adversary has to tell which key is which.

One natural question is whether or not this new game is equivalent to our previous definitions.

It is.

As a bit of a warmup, let's prove this equivalence.

IND-Both-CCA≤2⋅IND-CCA\text{IND-Both-CCA} \leq 2 \cdot \text{IND-CCA}IND-Both-CCA≤2⋅IND-CCA

The idea of this reduction is that we can replace k0k_0k0​ from the first encapsulation with a random key, because of IND-CCA\text{IND-CCA}IND-CCA security. This then allows us to swap k0k_0k0​ with k1k_1k1​, and then walk our way backwards, giving us a bound for ϵ(IND-Both-CCAb)\epsilon(\text{IND-Both-CCA}_b)ϵ(IND-Both-CCAb​).

We start by extracting out the encapsulation in IND-Both-CCAb\text{IND-Both-CCA}_bIND-Both-CCAb​, using IND-CCA\text{IND-CCA}IND-CCA:

IND-Both-CCAb=Wb Challenge():‾ (kb,c)←super.Challenge() k_(1−b)←RK seen←seen∪{c} return (k0,k1,c)⊗1{GetPk,Decap}∘IND-CCA0\text{IND-Both-CCA}_b = \begin{aligned} &\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\text{W}_b$ }\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{Challenge}():}\cr &\ (k_b, c) \gets \texttt{super.Challenge}() \cr &\ k\_{(1 - b)} \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K} \cr &\ \text{seen} \gets \text{seen} \cup \{c\}\cr &\ \texttt{return } (k_0, k_1, c) \cr \end{aligned} }\cr &\otimes 1\{\texttt{GetPk}, \texttt{Decap}\} \end{aligned} \circ \text{IND-CCA}_0IND-Both-CCAb​=​​Wb​ ​Challenge():​ (kb​,c)←super.Challenge() k_(1−b)R​K seen←seen∪{c} return (k0​,k1​,c)​​⊗1{GetPk,Decap}​∘IND-CCA0​

Using this, we can already march some of the way forward, giving us:

IND-Both-CCAb=Wb∘IND-CCA0≈ϵ1Wb∘IND-CCA1\text{IND-Both-CCA}_b = W_b \circ \text{IND-CCA}_0 \stackrel{\epsilon_1}{\approx} W_b \circ \text{IND-CCA}_1IND-Both-CCAb​=Wb​∘IND-CCA0​≈ϵ1​Wb​∘IND-CCA1​

Now, one thing we can note is that:

W0∘IND-CCA1=W1∘IND-CCA1W_0 \circ \text{IND-CCA}_1 = W_1 \circ \text{IND-CCA}_1W0​∘IND-CCA1​=W1​∘IND-CCA1​

To notice this, first expand out the game:

Wb∘IND-CCA1=seen←∅(sk,pk)←RGen()GetPk():‾ return pkChallenge():‾ (∙,c)←Encap(pk) kb←RK k_(1−b)←RK seen←seen∪{c} return (k0,k1,c)Decap(c):‾ assert c∉seen return Decap(sk,c)W_b \circ \text{IND-CCA}_1 = \begin{aligned} \boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\text{seen} \gets \emptyset\cr &(\text{sk}, \text{pk}) \xleftarrow{R} \text{Gen}()\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{GetPk}():}\cr &\ \texttt{return } \text{pk} \cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{Challenge}():}\cr &\ (\bullet, c) \gets \text{Encap}(\text{pk}) \cr &\ k_b \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\ k\_{(1 - b)} \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\ \text{seen} \gets \text{seen} \cup \{c\}\cr &\ \texttt{return } (k_0, k_1, c) \cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{Decap}(c):}\cr &\ \texttt{assert } c \notin \text{seen}\cr &\ \texttt{return } \text{Decap}(\text{sk}, c) \cr \end{aligned} } \end{aligned}Wb​∘IND-CCA1​=​seen←∅(sk,pk)R​Gen()GetPk():​ return pkChallenge():​ (∙,c)←Encap(pk) kb​R​K k_(1−b)R​K seen←seen∪{c} return (k0​,k1​,c)Decap(c):​ assert c∈/seen return Decap(sk,c)​​​

Because both k0k_0k0​ and k1k_1k1​ get sampled at random, it doesn't matter which order they have.

We can now align these togethers to get:

IND-Both-CCA0=W0∘IND-CCA0≈ϵ1W0∘IND-CCA1=W1∘IND-CCA1≈ϵ1W1∘IND-CCA0=IND-Both-CCA1\begin{aligned} \text{IND-Both-CCA}_0 &= W_0 \circ \text{IND-CCA}_0\cr &\stackrel{\epsilon_1}{\approx} W_0 \circ \text{IND-CCA}_1\cr &= W_1 \circ \text{IND-CCA}_1\cr &\stackrel{\epsilon_1}{\approx} W_1 \circ \text{IND-CCA}_0\cr &= \text{IND-Both-CCA}_1\cr \cr \end{aligned}IND-Both-CCA0​​=W0​∘IND-CCA0​≈ϵ1​W0​∘IND-CCA1​=W1​∘IND-CCA1​≈ϵ1​W1​∘IND-CCA0​=IND-Both-CCA1​​

which gives us our result.

□\square□

Now, for the other direction.

IND-Both-CCA≤IND-CCA\text{IND-Both-CCA} \leq \text{IND-CCA}IND-Both-CCA≤IND-CCA

The idea of this proof is that we can emulate IND-CCA\text{IND-CCA}IND-CCA using IND-Both-CCA\text{IND-Both-CCA}IND-Both-CCA by dropping one of the keys. The question is: which key do we drop? Because we can't distinguish between k0k_0k0​ and k1k_1k1​, it doesn't matter which one we choose, essentially.

First, let's define the following wrapper package:

Wb:=Challenge():‾ (k0,k1,c)←super.Challenge() return (kb,c)⊗1{GetPk,Decap}W_b := \boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\underline{\mathtt{Challenge}():}\cr &\ (k_0, k_1, c) \gets \texttt{super.Challenge}() \cr &\ \texttt{return } (k_b, c) \cr \end{aligned} } \otimes 1\{\texttt{GetPk}, \texttt{Decap}\}Wb​:=​Challenge():​ (k0​,k1​,c)←super.Challenge() return (kb​,c)​​⊗1{GetPk,Decap}

This perfectly emulates IND-CCAb\text{IND-CCA}_bIND-CCAb​ when composed with IND-Both-CCA0\text{IND-Both-CCA}_0IND-Both-CCA0​:

Wb∘IND-Both-CCA0=IND-CCAbW_b \circ \text{IND-Both-CCA}_0 = \text{IND-CCA}_bWb​∘IND-Both-CCA0​=IND-CCAb​

With IND-Both-CCA1\text{IND-Both-CCA}_1IND-Both-CCA1​ on the other hand, the bit is flipped:

Wb∘IND-Both-CCA1=IND-CCA_(1−b)W_b \circ \text{IND-Both-CCA}_1 = \text{IND-CCA}\_{(1 - b)}Wb​∘IND-Both-CCA1​=IND-CCA_(1−b)

This is enough for us to write:

IND-CCA0=W0∘IND-Both-CCA0≈ϵ1W0∘IND-Both-CCA1=IND-CCA1\begin{aligned} \text{IND-CCA}_0 &= W_0 \circ \text{IND-Both-CCA}_0\cr &\stackrel{\epsilon_1}{\approx} W_0 \circ \text{IND-Both-CCA}_1\cr &= \text{IND-CCA}_1\cr \end{aligned}IND-CCA0​​=W0​∘IND-Both-CCA0​≈ϵ1​W0​∘IND-Both-CCA1​=IND-CCA1​​

Which gives us the reduction we sought.

□\square□

Real-or-Random is Essential

These definitions turned out to be equivalent, but both fit into a kind of "real-or-random" paradigm: one of the keys is randomly selected, while the other is related to the ciphertext. This is a general kind of paradigm, which can be used to define the security of other schemes as well. It's useful to stay within this paradigm, since phrasing all of our security definitions in terms of real-or-random makes it easier to do reductions.

One alternative paradigm, that gets used for public key encryption, is "left-or-right". With this approach, instead of having a random output and a real output, you instead have two outputs, and you try and distinguish between them.

For the KEM case, this would give the following game:

IND-LRb (sk,pk)←RGen()GetPk():‾ return pkChallenge():‾ (k0,c0)←Encap(pk) (k1,c1)←Encap(pk) return (k0,k1,cb)\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\text{IND-LR}_b$ }\cr \cr &(\text{sk}, \text{pk}) \xleftarrow{R} \text{Gen}()\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{GetPk}():}\cr &\ \texttt{return } \text{pk} \cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{Challenge}():}\cr &\ (k_0, c_0) \gets \text{Encap}(\text{pk}) \cr &\ (k_1, c_1) \gets \text{Encap}(\text{pk}) \cr &\ \texttt{return } (k_0, k_1, c_b) \cr \end{aligned} }​IND-LRb​ ​(sk,pk)R​Gen()GetPk():​ return pkChallenge():​ (k0​,c0​)←Encap(pk) (k1​,c1​)←Encap(pk) return (k0​,k1​,cb​)​​

Unfortunately, this definition fails to capture a useful notion. The issue is that we have no guarantee that the key is sufficiently random, which makes it not usable for encryption later.

As an example, consider the following KEM:

Encap(pk):‾ c←RC return (0,c)Decap(sk,c):‾ return 0\begin{aligned} &\underline{\text{Encap}(\text{pk}):}\cr &\ c \xleftarrow{R} \bold{C} \cr &\ \texttt{return } (0, c)\cr \cr &\underline{\text{Decap}(\text{sk}, c):}\cr &\ \texttt{return } 0 \end{aligned}​Encap(pk):​ cR​C return (0,c)Decap(sk,c):​ return 0​

This KEM always returns the same key for encapsulation and decapsulation, which makes it completely useless to construct a secure public key encryption scheme. It does, however, satisfy the IND-LR\text{IND-LR}IND-LR definition of security above. This is because (0,0,cb)(0, 0, c_b)(0,0,cb​) contains no information about bbb.

Constructing KEMs

We've now seen a bit of how KEMs work in theory, but we've yet to actually see an example of making one. In this section, we go over a few potential constructions of KEMs, and show that they're secure, under appropriate assumptions.

From RSA

Let's start with RSA. There are thousands of good explanations of RSA, so I'll settle for a bad, but short, explanation.

In RSA, your public key consists of a modulus NNN, and a number eee. Your secret key consists of a factorization p,qp, qp,q such that N=p⋅qN = p \cdot qN=p⋅q, along with a secret exponent ddd, such that

d⋅e≡1modφ(N)d \cdot e \equiv 1 \mod \varphi(N)d⋅e≡1modφ(N)

These parameters give us a trapdoor permutation for the set Z/(N)\mathbb{Z}/(N)Z/(N):

F(x):=xemodNF−1(y):=ydmodN\begin{aligned} F(x) &:= x^e \mod N\cr F^{-1}(y) &:= y^d \mod N\cr \end{aligned}F(x)F−1(y)​:=xemodN:=ydmodN​

The function FFF is a permutation, with F−1F^{-1}F−1 its inverse. Computing the inverse should be hard without knowing the secret exponent ddd, or being able to factor NNN.

We make this security notion precise with the following game:

RSAb (d,(N,e))←RGen()x←RZ/(N)y←xemodNInstance():‾ return (N,e,y)Guess(x^):‾ return b=0∧x^=x\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\text{RSA}_b$ }\cr \cr &(d, (N, e)) \xleftarrow{R} \text{Gen}()\cr &x \xleftarrow{R} \mathbb{Z}/(N)\cr &y \gets x^e \mod N\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{Instance}():}\cr &\ \texttt{return } (N, e, y) \cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{Guess}(\hat{x}):}\cr &\ \texttt{return } b = 0 \land \hat{x} = x\cr \end{aligned} }​RSAb​ ​(d,(N,e))R​Gen()xR​Z/(N)y←xemodNInstance():​ return (N,e,y)Guess(x^):​ return b=0∧x^=x​​

The adversary makes guesses for the pre-image of the permutation, and it should be difficult for them to succeed in their guess. If the adversary has a good strategy for guessing, then they'll be able to figure out what bbb is.

We can use RSA to create a KEM. The pre-image xxx will be our key, and then y:=xemodNy := x^e \mod Ny:=xemodN is our ciphertext, hiding the key. The recipient can use their secret to unwrap xxx from this ciphertext. Now, because Z/(N)\mathbb{Z}/(N)Z/(N) may not be a very useful key by itself, we also make use of a hash function H:Z/(N)→KH : \mathbb{Z}/(N) \to \bold{K}H:Z/(N)→K, so that we can derive a more useful key from xxx.

For example, if we wanted to use our key for encryption with AES, or ChaCha20, we'd want to use a hash function from integers to 256 bit keys.

More formally, we define the following KEM:

Gen():‾ (d,(N,e))←RSA.Gen() return ((N,d),(N,e))Encap((N,e)):‾ x←RZ/(N) y←xemodN return (H(x),y)Decap((N,d),y):‾ x←ydmodN return H(x)\begin{aligned} &\underline{\text{Gen}():}\cr &\ (d, (N, e)) \gets \text{RSA}.\text{Gen}()\cr &\ \texttt{return } ((N, d), (N, e)) \cr \cr &\underline{\text{Encap}((N, e)):}\cr &\ x \xleftarrow{R} \mathbb{Z}/(N)\cr &\ y \gets x^e \mod N\cr &\ \texttt{return } (H(x), y)\cr \cr &\underline{\text{Decap}((N, d), y):}\cr &\ x \gets y^d \mod N\cr &\ \texttt{return } H(x)\cr \end{aligned}​Gen():​ (d,(N,e))←RSA.Gen() return ((N,d),(N,e))Encap((N,e)):​ xR​Z/(N) y←xemodN return (H(x),y)Decap((N,d),y):​ x←ydmodN return H(x)​

Because the RSA function is a permutation, correctness is satisfied.

As for security, this isn't a trivial matter. First, we'll model our hash function HHH as a random oracle, where the outputs will be generated perfectly at random, on demand. Second, rather than considering normal IND-CCA\text{IND-CCA}IND-CCA security, instead we'll consider IND-CCA-1\text{IND-CCA-1}IND-CCA-1 security, where the adversary can only make a single challenge query. Making QQQ challenge queries instead of just a single one only decreases security by a factor of QQQ, as can be shown via a hybrid argument. (My post on state-separable proofs contains a proof of this in the general case).

IND-CCA-1≤2⋅RSA\text{IND-CCA-1} \leq 2 \cdot \text{RSA}IND-CCA-1≤2⋅RSA

First, let's write down the IND-CCA-1\text{IND-CCA-1}IND-CCA-1 game in this context.

IND-CCA-1b seen←∅((N,d),(N,e))←RGen()GetPk():‾ return (N,e)(1) Challenge():‾ x←RZ/(N) y←xemodN k0←H(x) k1←RK seen←seen∪{y} return (kb,y)Decap(y):‾ assert y∉seen return H(ydmodN)h[⋅]←⊥H(x)‾: if x∉h h[x]←RK return h[x]\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\text{IND-CCA-1}_b$ }\cr \cr &\text{seen} \gets \emptyset\cr &((N, d), (N, e)) \xleftarrow{R} \text{Gen}()\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{GetPk}():}\cr &\ \texttt{return } (N, e) \cr \cr &\underline{(1)\ \mathtt{Challenge}():}\cr &\ x \xleftarrow{R} \mathbb{Z}/(N)\cr &\ y \gets x^e \mod N\cr &\ k_0 \gets \texttt{H}(x)\cr &\ k_1 \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\ \text{seen} \gets \text{seen} \cup \{y\}\cr &\ \texttt{return } (k_b, y) \cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{Decap}(y):}\cr &\ \texttt{assert } y \notin \text{seen}\cr &\ \texttt{return } \mathtt{H}(y^d \mod N) \cr \cr &h[\cdot] \gets \bot\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{H}(x)}:\cr &\ \texttt{if } x \notin h\cr &\quad\ h[x] \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\ \texttt{return } h[x]\cr \end{aligned} }​IND-CCA-1b​ ​seen←∅((N,d),(N,e))R​Gen()GetPk():​ return (N,e)(1) Challenge():​ xR​Z/(N) y←xemodN k0​←H(x) k1​R​K seen←seen∪{y} return (kb​,y)Decap(y):​ assert y∈/seen return H(ydmodN)h[⋅]←⊥H(x)​: if x∈/h h[x]R​K return h[x]​​

The (1)(1)(1) notation means that Challenge\texttt{Challenge}Challenge can only be queried a single time. We've also replaced the hash function with a lazily initialized table of random values. This is why we're doing our proof in the "random oracle model", since the hash function is being modelled this way.

Next, we follow the same strategy as in Theorem 12.2 of Boneh and Shoup.

Rather than having our table hhh be used for the pre-images xxx, instead we'll setup a table h′h'h′ for the images yyy. This will allow us to minimize our use of the secret key ddd in decapsulation queries, which makes it easier to extract out the RSA functionality for our package.

Since we only have a single challenge query, we can generate the instance before Challenge\texttt{Challenge}Challenge is called. We'll also be able to do a lot of tricks with the decapsulation queries, but it's easier to explain those after seeing the new game:

Γb0 ((N,d),(N,e))←RGen() x^←RZ/(N) y^←x^emodN k0←RKGetPk():‾ return (N,e)(1) Challenge():‾ k1←RK return (kb,y^)h[⋅]←⊥Decap(y):‾ assert y≠y^ if y∉h h[y]←RK return h[y]H(x)‾: if x=x^ return k0 y←xemodN if y∉h h[y]←RK return h[y]\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\Gamma^0_b$ }\cr \cr &((N, d), (N, e)) \xleftarrow{R} \text{Gen}()\cr &\ \hat{x} \xleftarrow{R} \mathbb{Z}/(N)\cr &\ \hat{y} \gets \hat{x}^e \mod N\cr &\ k_0 \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{GetPk}():}\cr &\ \texttt{return } (N, e) \cr \cr &\underline{(1)\ \mathtt{Challenge}():}\cr &\ k_1 \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\ \texttt{return } (k_b, \hat{y}) \cr \cr &h[\cdot] \gets \bot\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{Decap}(y):}\cr &\ \texttt{assert } y \neq \hat{y}\cr &\ \texttt{if } y \notin h\cr &\quad\ h[y] \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\ \texttt{return } h[y] \cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{H}(x)}:\cr &\ \texttt{if } x = \hat{x}\cr &\quad\ \texttt{return } k_0\cr &\ y \gets x^e \mod N\cr &\ \texttt{if } y \notin h\cr &\quad\ h[y] \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\ \texttt{return } h[y]\cr \end{aligned} }​Γb0​ ​((N,d),(N,e))R​Gen() x^R​Z/(N) y^​←x^emodN k0​R​KGetPk():​ return (N,e)(1) Challenge():​ k1​R​K return (kb​,y^​)h[⋅]←⊥Decap(y):​ assert y=y^​ if y∈/h h[y]R​K return h[y]H(x)​: if x=x^ return k0​ y←xemodN if y∈/h h[y]R​K return h[y]​​

The big trick we've pulled in this game is in our decapsulation function. By having a hash table for the images yyy, we avoid the need to make use of the secret key ddd when decapsulating. Whereas we'd normally compute x←ydmodNx \gets y^d \mod Nx←ydmodN, and then query H(x)\texttt{H}(x)H(x), because our hash function then computes xemodNx^e \mod NxemodN to index into our table, we can avoid all of that, and use the table ourselves.

Naturally, we have IND-CCA-1b=Γb0\text{IND-CCA-1}_b = \Gamma^0_bIND-CCA-1b​=Γb0​.

From this point on, it's relatively straight sailing.

We start by extracting out the RSA functionality:

Γb0=Γb1 (N,e,y^)←Instance() k0←RKGetPk():‾ return (N,e)(1) Challenge():‾ k1←RK return (kb,y^)h[⋅]←⊥Decap(y):‾ assert y≠y^ if y∉h h[y]←RK return h[y]H(x)‾: if Guess(x) return k0 y←xemodN if y∉h h[y]←RK return h[y]∘RSA0\Gamma^0_b = \boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\Gamma^1_b$ }\cr \cr &(N, e, \hat{y}) \gets \texttt{Instance}()\cr &\ k_0 \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{GetPk}():}\cr &\ \texttt{return } (N, e) \cr \cr &\underline{(1)\ \mathtt{Challenge}():}\cr &\ k_1 \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\ \texttt{return } (k_b, \hat{y}) \cr \cr &h[\cdot] \gets \bot\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{Decap}(y):}\cr &\ \texttt{assert } y \neq \hat{y}\cr &\ \texttt{if } y \notin h\cr &\quad\ h[y] \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\ \texttt{return } h[y] \cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{H}(x)}:\cr &\ \texttt{if } \texttt{Guess}(x)\cr &\quad\ \texttt{return } k_0\cr &\ y \gets x^e \mod N\cr &\ \texttt{if } y \notin h\cr &\quad\ h[y] \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\ \texttt{return } h[y]\cr \end{aligned} } \circ \text{RSA}_0Γb0​=​Γb1​ ​(N,e,y^​)←Instance() k0​R​KGetPk():​ return (N,e)(1) Challenge():​ k1​R​K return (kb​,y^​)h[⋅]←⊥Decap(y):​ assert y=y^​ if y∈/h h[y]R​K return h[y]H(x)​: if Guess(x) return k0​ y←xemodN if y∈/h h[y]R​K return h[y]​​∘RSA0​

Now we use the RSA0\text{RSA}_0RSA0​ game to determine if we need to return k0k_0k0​ in our hash function. Next, note that if we switch to using RSA1\text{RSA}_1RSA1​, we get the following game:

Γb1∘RSA1=Γb2 (N,e,y^)←Instance()GetPk():‾ return (N,e)(1) Challenge():‾ k0←RK k1←RK return (kb,y^)h[⋅]←⊥Decap(y):‾ assert y≠y^ if y∉h h[y]←RK return h[y]H(x)‾: y←xemodN if y∉h h[y]←RK return h[y]\Gamma^1_b \circ \text{RSA}_1 = \boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\Gamma^2_b$ }\cr \cr &(N, e, \hat{y}) \gets \texttt{Instance}()\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{GetPk}():}\cr &\ \texttt{return } (N, e) \cr \cr &\underline{(1)\ \mathtt{Challenge}():}\cr &\ k_0 \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\ k_1 \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\ \texttt{return } (k_b, \hat{y}) \cr \cr &h[\cdot] \gets \bot\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{Decap}(y):}\cr &\ \texttt{assert } y \neq \hat{y}\cr &\ \texttt{if } y \notin h\cr &\quad\ h[y] \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\ \texttt{return } h[y] \cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{H}(x)}:\cr &\ y \gets x^e \mod N\cr &\ \texttt{if } y \notin h\cr &\quad\ h[y] \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\ \texttt{return } h[y]\cr \end{aligned} }Γb1​∘RSA1​=​Γb2​ ​(N,e,y^​)←Instance()GetPk():​ return (N,e)(1) Challenge():​ k0​R​K k1​R​K return (kb​,y^​)h[⋅]←⊥Decap(y):​ assert y=y^​ if y∈/h h[y]R​K return h[y]H(x)​: y←xemodN if y∈/h h[y]R​K return h[y]​​

And in this game, the difference between k0k_0k0​ and k1k_1k1​ is just a matter of naming. Because of this, Γ02=Γ12\Gamma^2_0 = \Gamma^2_1Γ02​=Γ12​.

We can now tie everything together, to get:

IND-CCA-10=Γ00=Γ01∘RSA0≈ϵ1Γ01∘RSA1=Γ02=Γ12=Γ11∘RSA1≈ϵ1Γ11∘RSA0=Γ10=IND-CCA-11\begin{aligned} \text{IND-CCA-1}_0 &= \Gamma^0_0\cr &= \Gamma^1_0 \circ \text{RSA}_0\cr &\stackrel{\epsilon_1}{\approx} \Gamma^1_0 \circ \text{RSA}_1\cr &= \Gamma^2_0\cr &= \Gamma^2_1\cr &= \Gamma^1_1 \circ \text{RSA}_1\cr &\stackrel{\epsilon_1}{\approx} \Gamma^1_1 \circ \text{RSA}_0\cr &= \Gamma^0_1\cr &= \text{IND-CCA-1}_1\cr \end{aligned}IND-CCA-10​​=Γ00​=Γ01​∘RSA0​≈ϵ1​Γ01​∘RSA1​=Γ02​=Γ12​=Γ11​∘RSA1​≈ϵ1​Γ11​∘RSA0​=Γ10​=IND-CCA-11​​

And this yields our result.

□\square□

From Groups

Another way to construct a KEM is with a cryptographic group, like a suitable elliptic curve.

This is a group G\mathbb{G}G of prime order qqq, generated by GGG, and with an associated field of scalars Fq\mathbb{F}_qFq​.

A key pair for the KEM will be a scalar aaa, for the private key, and a point A:=a⋅G{A := a \cdot G}A:=a⋅G, for the public key. In order to encapsulate a key, we generate a random scalar bbb, set B:=b⋅G{B := b \cdot G}B:=b⋅G as our encapsulation, and H(b⋅A)H(b \cdot A)H(b⋅A) as the key. The receiver can set H(a⋅B)H(a \cdot B)H(a⋅B) as their key, arriving at the same result because of commutativity:

a⋅B=a⋅b⋅G=b⋅a⋅G=b⋅Aa \cdot B = a \cdot b \cdot G = b \cdot a \cdot G = b \cdot Aa⋅B=a⋅b⋅G=b⋅a⋅G=b⋅A

More formally, given a cryptographic group G\mathbb{G}G, and a hash function H:G2→KH : \mathbb{G}^2 \to \bold{K}H:G2→K, we define the KEM as follows:

Gen():‾ a←RFq A←a⋅G return (a,A)Encap(A):‾ b←RFq B←b⋅G C←b⋅A return (H(B,C),B)Decap(a,B):‾ C←a⋅B return H(B,C)\begin{aligned} &\underline{\text{Gen}():}\cr &\ a \xleftarrow{R} \mathbb{F}_q\cr &\ A \gets a \cdot G\cr &\ \texttt{return } (a, A) \cr \cr &\underline{\text{Encap}(A):}\cr &\ b \xleftarrow{R} \mathbb{F}_q\cr &\ B \gets b \cdot G\cr &\ C \gets b \cdot A\cr &\ \texttt{return } (H(B, C), B)\cr \cr &\underline{\text{Decap}(a, B):}\cr &\ C \gets a \cdot B\cr &\ \texttt{return } H(B, C)\cr \end{aligned}​Gen():​ aR​Fq​ A←a⋅G return (a,A)Encap(A):​ bR​Fq​ B←b⋅G C←b⋅A return (H(B,C),B)Decap(a,B):​ C←a⋅B return H(B,C)​

One slight difference from the brief presentation above is that we hash both BBB and CCC, rather than just CCC. This makes the security proof easier.

To characterize the security of the KEM, we need to have some kind notion of security for the group itself. The notion we'll be relying on (at least, in our proof), is the "interactive computational Diffie-Hellman" problem. This states, essentially, that given two points A=a⋅GA = a \cdot GA=a⋅G and B=b⋅GB = b \cdot GB=b⋅G, it should be hard to find C=ab⋅GC = ab \cdot GC=ab⋅G, even given access to an oracle which tells you whether or not two points B^\hat{B}B^ and C^\hat{C}C^ satisfy the relation a⋅B^=C^a \cdot \hat{B} = \hat{C}a⋅B^=C^.

We capture this notion through a guessing game:

ICDHb a,b←RGen()A←a⋅GB←b⋅GC←a⋅BInstance():‾ return (A,B)Query(B^,C^):‾ return a⋅B^=C^Guess(C^):‾ return b=0∧C^=C\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\text{ICDH}_b$ }\cr \cr &a, b \xleftarrow{R} \text{Gen}()\cr &A \gets a \cdot G\cr &B \gets b \cdot G\cr &C \gets a \cdot B\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{Instance}():}\cr &\ \texttt{return } (A, B) \cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{Query}(\hat{B}, \hat{C}):}\cr &\ \texttt{return } a \cdot \hat{B} = \hat{C}\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{Guess}(\hat{C}):}\cr &\ \texttt{return } b = 0 \land \hat{C} = C\cr \end{aligned} }​ICDHb​ ​a,bR​Gen()A←a⋅GB←b⋅GC←a⋅BInstance():​ return (A,B)Query(B^,C^):​ return a⋅B^=C^Guess(C^):​ return b=0∧C^=C​​

This notion suffices to prove IND-CCA\text{IND-CCA}IND-CCA security of the KEM:

IND-CCA-1≤2⋅ICDHb\text{IND-CCA-1} \leq 2 \cdot \text{ICDH}_bIND-CCA-1≤2⋅ICDHb​

We'll model our hash function as a random oracle, like with RSA.

Let's start by explicitly writing down the IND-CCA-1\text{IND-CCA-1}IND-CCA-1 game in this context:

IND-CCA-1b seen←∅a←RFqA←a⋅GGetPk():‾ return A(1)Challenge():‾ b←RFq B←b⋅G C←c⋅C k0←H(B,C) k1←RK seen←seen∪{B} return (kb,B)Decap(B):‾ assert B∉seen return H(B,a⋅B)h[⋅]←⊥H(B,C):‾ if (B,C)∉h h[B,C]←RK return h[B,C]\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\text{IND-CCA-1}_b$ }\cr \cr &\text{seen} \gets \emptyset\cr &a \xleftarrow{R} \mathbb{F}_q\cr &A \gets a \cdot G\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{GetPk}():}\cr &\ \texttt{return } A\cr \cr &\underline{(1) \mathtt{Challenge}():}\cr &\ b \xleftarrow{R} \mathbb{F}_q\cr &\ B \gets b \cdot G\cr &\ C \gets c \cdot C\cr &\ k_0 \gets \texttt{H}(B, C)\cr &\ k_1 \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\ \text{seen} \gets \text{seen} \cup \{B\}\cr &\ \texttt{return } (k_b, B) \cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{Decap}(B):}\cr &\ \texttt{assert } B \notin \text{seen}\cr &\ \texttt{return } \texttt{H}(B, a \cdot B) \cr \cr &h[\cdot] \gets \bot\cr &\underline{\mathtt{H}(B, C):}\cr &\ \texttt{if } (B, C) \notin h\cr &\quad\ h[B, C] \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\ \texttt{return } h[B, C]\cr \end{aligned} }​IND-CCA-1b​ ​seen←∅aR​Fq​A←a⋅GGetPk():​ return A(1)Challenge():​ bR​Fq​ B←b⋅G C←c⋅C k0​←H(B,C) k1​R​K seen←seen∪{B} return (kb​,B)Decap(B):​ assert B∈/seen return H(B,a⋅B)h[⋅]←⊥H(B,C):​ if (B,C)∈/h h[B,C]R​K return h[B,C]​​

Next, like with the RSA kem proof, we need to minimize our use of the secret key when decapsulating. We follow the same strategy as in Theorem 12.4 of Boneh and Shoup.

We replace our hash table for pairs (B,C)(B, C)(B,C) with a table for BBB, when C=a⋅BC = a \cdot BC=a⋅B, and a table for (B,C)(B, C)(B,C), when BBB and CCC are not related. Since we only have a single challenge query, we can also lift generation of those values outside the challenge.

This gives us the following game:

IND-CCA-1b=Γb0 a,b←RFqA←a⋅GB←b⋅GC←a⋅B k0←RKGetPk():‾ return A(1)Challenge():‾ k1←RK return (kb,B)h[⋅],h′[⋅]←⊥Decap(B^):‾ assert B^≠B if B^∉h′ h′[B^]←RK return h′[B^]H(B^,C^):‾ if (B^,C^)∉h if a⋅B^=C^ if C^=C h′[B^]←k0 if B^∉h′ h′[B^]←RK h[B^,C^]←h′[B^] else  h[B^,C^]←RK return h[B^,C^]\text{IND-CCA-1}_b = \boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\Gamma^0_b$ }\cr \cr &a, b \xleftarrow{R} \mathbb{F}_q\cr &A \gets a \cdot G\cr &B \gets b \cdot G\cr &C \gets a \cdot B\cr &\ k_0 \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{GetPk}():}\cr &\ \texttt{return } A\cr \cr &\underline{(1) \mathtt{Challenge}():}\cr &\ k_1 \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\ \texttt{return } (k_b, B) \cr \cr &h[\cdot], h'[\cdot] \gets \bot\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{Decap}(\hat{B}):}\cr &\ \texttt{assert } \hat{B} \neq B\cr &\ \texttt{if } \hat{B} \notin h'\cr &\quad\ h'[\hat{B}] \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\ \texttt{return } h'[\hat{B}] \cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{H}(\hat{B}, \hat{C}):}\cr &\ \texttt{if } (\hat{B}, \hat{C}) \notin h \cr &\quad\ \texttt{if } a \cdot \hat{B} = \hat{C}\cr &\quad\quad\ \texttt{if } \hat{C} = C \cr &\quad\quad\quad\ h'[\hat{B}] \gets k_0\cr &\quad\quad\ \texttt{if } \hat{B} \notin h' \cr &\quad\quad\quad\ h'[\hat{B}] \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\quad\quad\ h[\hat{B}, \hat{C}] \gets h'[\hat{B}]\cr &\quad\ \texttt{else }\cr &\quad\quad\ h[\hat{B}, \hat{C}] \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\ \texttt{return } h[\hat{B}, \hat{C}]\cr \end{aligned} }IND-CCA-1b​=​Γb0​ ​a,bR​Fq​A←a⋅GB←b⋅GC←a⋅B k0​R​KGetPk():​ return A(1)Challenge():​ k1​R​K return (kb​,B)h[⋅],h′[⋅]←⊥Decap(B^):​ assert B^=B if B^∈/h′ h′[B^]R​K return h′[B^]H(B^,C^):​ if (B^,C^)∈/h if a⋅B^=C^ if C^=C h′[B^]←k0​ if B^∈/h′ h′[B^]R​K h[B^,C^]←h′[B^] else  h[B^,C^]R​K return h[B^,C^]​​

Basically, we maintain the invariant that a⋅B^=C^⟹h[B^,C^]=h′[B^]a \cdot \hat{B} = \hat{C} \implies h[\hat{B}, \hat{C}] = h'[\hat{B}]a⋅B^=C^⟹h[B^,C^]=h′[B^]. this allows us to make decapsulation queries without making use of the secret key. This will make extracting out the ICDH\text{ICDH}ICDH game much easier. This extraction is also made easier in that the query a⋅B^=C^a \cdot \hat{B} = \hat{C}a⋅B^=C^ is precisely the kind of query we can do in this game.

The next step is to extract out ICDH\text{ICDH}ICDH:

Γb0=Γb1 (A,B)←Instance() k0←RKGetPk():‾ return A(1)Challenge():‾ k1←RK return (kb,B)h[⋅],h′[⋅]←⊥Decap(B^):‾ assert B^≠B if B^∉h′ h′[B^]←RK return h′[B^]H(B^,C^):‾ if (B^,C^)∉h if Query(B^,C^) if Guess(C^) h′[B^]←k0 if B^∉h′ h′[B^]←RK h[B^,C^]←h′[B^] else  h[B^,C^]←RK return h[B^,C^]∘ICDH0\Gamma^0_b = \boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\Gamma^1_b$ }\cr \cr &(A, B) \gets \texttt{Instance()}\cr &\ k_0 \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{GetPk}():}\cr &\ \texttt{return } A\cr \cr &\underline{(1) \mathtt{Challenge}():}\cr &\ k_1 \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\ \texttt{return } (k_b, B) \cr \cr &h[\cdot], h'[\cdot] \gets \bot\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{Decap}(\hat{B}):}\cr &\ \texttt{assert } \hat{B} \neq B\cr &\ \texttt{if } \hat{B} \notin h'\cr &\quad\ h'[\hat{B}] \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\ \texttt{return } h'[\hat{B}] \cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{H}(\hat{B}, \hat{C}):}\cr &\ \texttt{if } (\hat{B}, \hat{C}) \notin h \cr &\quad\ \texttt{if } \texttt{Query}(\hat{B}, \hat{C})\cr &\quad\quad\ \texttt{if } \texttt{Guess}(\hat{C}) \cr &\quad\quad\quad\ h'[\hat{B}] \gets k_0\cr &\quad\quad\ \texttt{if } \hat{B} \notin h' \cr &\quad\quad\quad\ h'[\hat{B}] \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\quad\quad\ h[\hat{B}, \hat{C}] \gets h'[\hat{B}]\cr &\quad\ \texttt{else }\cr &\quad\quad\ h[\hat{B}, \hat{C}] \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\cr &\ \texttt{return } h[\hat{B}, \hat{C}]\cr \end{aligned} } \circ \text{ICDH}_0Γb0​=​Γb1​ ​(A,B)←Instance() k0​R​KGetPk():​ return A(1)Challenge():​ k1​R​K return (kb​,B)h[⋅],h′[⋅]←⊥Decap(B^):​ assert B^=B if B^∈/h′ h′[B^]R​K return h′[B^]H(B^,C^):​ if (B^,C^)∈/h if Query(B^,C^) if Guess(C^) h′[B^]←k0​ if B^∈/h′ h′[B^]R​K h[B^,C^]←h′[B^] else  h[B^,C^]R​K return h[B^,C^]​​∘ICDH0​

Now, notice that in the game Γb1∘ICDH1\Gamma^1_b \circ \text{ICDH}_1Γb1​∘ICDH1​, k0k_0k0​ isn't used anywhere but inside of Challenge\texttt{Challenge}Challenge, because Guess\texttt{Guess}Guess always returns 000. This means that the difference between k0k_0k0​ and k1k_1k1​ becomes a matter of naming, so:

Γ1_0∘ICDH_1=Γ1_1∘ICDH_1\Gamma^1\_0 \circ \text{ICDH}\_1 = \Gamma^1\_1 \circ \text{ICDH}\_1Γ1_0∘ICDH_1=Γ1_1∘ICDH_1

This is enough to make our full walk, and tie everything together:

IND-CCA-10=Γ00=Γ01∘ICDH0≈ϵ1Γ01∘ICDH1=Γ11∘ICDH1≈ϵ1Γ11∘ICDH0=Γ01=IND-CCA-11\begin{aligned} \text{IND-CCA-1}_0 &= \Gamma^0_0\cr &= \Gamma^1_0 \circ \text{ICDH}_0\cr &\stackrel{\epsilon_1}{\approx} \Gamma^1_0 \circ \text{ICDH}_1\cr &= \Gamma^1_1 \circ \text{ICDH}_1\cr &\stackrel{\epsilon_1}{\approx} \Gamma^1_1 \circ \text{ICDH}_0\cr &= \Gamma^1_0\cr &= \text{IND-CCA-1}_1\cr \end{aligned}IND-CCA-10​​=Γ00​=Γ01​∘ICDH0​≈ϵ1​Γ01​∘ICDH1​=Γ11​∘ICDH1​≈ϵ1​Γ11​∘ICDH0​=Γ01​=IND-CCA-11​​

□\square□

And Other Methods

Another method that's going to be increasingly important is using lattices to construct KEMs.

Both of the schemes I've mentioned in this post, using RSA, and using elliptic curves, will be broken by future quantum computers. This is why NIST started a competition in order to standardize KEMs secure against quantum computers.

Many of the candidates were based on lattices, including the finalist, Kyber.

Other candidates used different primitives, like isogenies, or random codes.

Composing KEMs

Talking about the post-quantum KEMs segues nicely into this next topic. Right now, we have very well tested and trusted KEMs, which aren't secure against quantum computers. We also have a new KEM which should be secure against quantum computers, but given its novelty, you may not trust it that much yet.

Because of this, many people are trying to deploy both schemes together in a hybrid fashion. This means that you can get post-quantum security if the new KEM stands the test of time, but you also don't sacrifice classical security if the new KEM you include happens to be flawed.

To achieve this, what you want is a way to combine KEMs, mixing together KEMs AAA and BBB to create a new KEM, which should be secure as long as at least one of the two ingredients is. If AAA is broken, that's fine as long as BBB is secure, and vice versa.

This construction is called a KEM combiner, and it can combine two KEMs in this way, without having to inspect how the KEMs work internally at all. The paper [^[GHP18]] goes over this notion of combiners, and presents a very elegant construction.

To encapsulate, you call each of the individual KEMs first, giving you (kA,cA)(k_A, c_A)(kA​,cA​) and (kB,cB)(k_B, c_B)(kB​,cB​). Next, (cA,cB)(c_A, c_B)(cA​,cB​) becomes your ciphertext. Now, you need some way to combine all of this information to derive a single key kkk. One idea would be to simply xor the two keys, giving you k←kA⊕kBk \gets k_A \oplus k_Bk←kA​⊕kB​. Unfortunately, this is not IND-CCA secure, because the resulting key is malleable.

The idea in this paper is instead to use a kind of pseudo-random function (PRF) to derive the result:

F(kA,kB,(cA,cB))F(k_A, k_B, (c_A, c_B))F(kA​,kB​,(cA​,cB​))

This is a special kind of PRF called a split-key PRF.

Split-Key PRFs in Theory

More formally, a split-key PRF is a function:

F:K0×K1×X→YF : \bold{K}_0 \times \bold{K}_1 \times \bold{X} \to \bold{Y}F:K0​×K1​×X→Y

We have two types for keys, K0\bold{K}_0K0​ and K1\bold{K}_1K1​, as well as an input type X\bold{X}X, and an output type Y\bold{Y}Y. The intuition for this function is that it should behave like a random function X→Y\bold{X} \to \bold{Y}X→Y as long as the adversary doesn't know either of the keys. Even if the adversary controls one of the keys, and can query the function FFF on different values for this key, they still shouldn't be able to distinguish this function from a random one.

We formalize this with a game:

SPLIT-PRFb(σ)  k_σ←RK0 seen←∅QueryF(k_(1−σ),x):‾ assert x∉seen y0←F(k0,k1,x) y1←RY return yb\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\text{SPLIT-PRF}_b(\sigma)$ }\cr &\ k\_{\sigma} \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}_0\cr &\ \text{seen} \gets \emptyset\cr \cr &\underline{\texttt{QueryF}(k\_{(1 - \sigma)}, x):}\cr &\ \texttt{assert } x \notin \text{seen}\cr &\ y_0 \gets F(k_0, k_1, x)\cr &\ y_1 \xleftarrow{R} \bold{Y}\cr &\ \texttt{return } y_b \end{aligned} }​SPLIT-PRFb​(σ) ​ k_σR​K0​ seen←∅QueryF(k_(1−σ),x):​ assert x∈/seen y0​←F(k0​,k1​,x) y1​R​Y return yb​​​

One subtlety is that we don't allow the adversary to query the same input point twice, even with different keys. A stronger security notion would be to allow queries to the same input with a different key, but we won't need that for proving the security of our KEM combination scheme.

Split-Key PRFs are Secure PRFs

[!note] Note: If you're convinced of this just from reading the section header, feel free to skip this section.

With a split-key PRF, we model security in a situation where the adversary can control one of the keys. When looking at the security of a PRF, the adversary doesn't control the key at all. One interesting fact is that a split-key PRF is necessarily a secure PRF, considering (k0,k1)(k_0, k_1)(k0​,k1​) as a single "key".

PRF≤SPLIT-PRF(σ)\text{PRF} \leq \text{SPLIT-PRF}(\sigma)PRF≤SPLIT-PRF(σ)

Let's recall the PRF game (in this context), briefly:

PRFb  k0←RK0 k1←RK1 seen←∅QueryF(x):‾ assert x∉seen y0←F(k0,k1,x) y1←RY return yb\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\text{PRF}_b$ }\cr \cr &\ k_0 \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}_0\cr &\ k_1 \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}_1\cr &\ \text{seen} \gets \emptyset\cr \cr &\underline{\texttt{QueryF}(x):}\cr &\ \texttt{assert } x \notin \text{seen}\cr &\ y_0 \gets F(k_0, k_1, x)\cr &\ y_1 \xleftarrow{R} \bold{Y}\cr &\ \texttt{return } y_b \end{aligned} }​PRFb​ ​ k0​R​K0​ k1​R​K1​ seen←∅QueryF(x):​ assert x∈/seen y0​←F(k0​,k1​,x) y1​R​Y return yb​​​

From here you just need to extract out the split-key game:

PRFb=Γ  k_(1−σ)←RK_(1−σ)QueryF(x):‾ return super.QueryF(k_(1−σ),x)∘SPLIT-PRFb(σ)  k_σ←RK0 seen←∅QueryF(k_(1−σ),x):‾ assert x∉seen y0←F(k0,k1,x) y1←RY return yb\text{PRF}_b = \boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\Gamma$ }\cr \cr &\ k\_{(1 - \sigma)} \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}\_{(1 - \sigma)}\cr \cr &\underline{\texttt{QueryF}(x):}\cr &\ \texttt{return } \texttt{super.QueryF}(k\_{(1 - \sigma)}, x) \end{aligned} } \circ \boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\text{SPLIT-PRF}_b(\sigma)$ }\cr \cr &\ k\_{\sigma} \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}_0\cr &\ \text{seen} \gets \emptyset\cr \cr &\underline{\texttt{QueryF}(k\_{(1 - \sigma)}, x):}\cr &\ \texttt{assert } x \notin \text{seen}\cr &\ y_0 \gets F(k_0, k_1, x)\cr &\ y_1 \xleftarrow{R} \bold{Y}\cr &\ \texttt{return } y_b \end{aligned} }PRFb​=​Γ ​ k_(1−σ)R​K_(1−σ)QueryF(x):​ return super.QueryF(k_(1−σ),x)​​∘​SPLIT-PRFb​(σ) ​ k_σR​K0​ seen←∅QueryF(k_(1−σ),x):​ assert x∈/seen y0​←F(k0​,k1​,x) y1​R​Y return yb​​​

This gives us:

PRF0=Γ∘SPLIT-PRF0(σ)≈ϵ1Γ∘SPLIT-PRF1(σ)=PRF1\text{PRF}_0 = \Gamma \circ \text{SPLIT-PRF}_0(\sigma) \stackrel{\epsilon_1}{\approx} \Gamma \circ \text{SPLIT-PRF}_1(\sigma) = \text{PRF}_1PRF0​=Γ∘SPLIT-PRF0​(σ)≈ϵ1​Γ∘SPLIT-PRF1​(σ)=PRF1​

concluding our proof.

□\square□

KEM Combination with PRF

It turns out that split-key PRFs precisely capture what we need to compose KEMs together. In this section, we formally define the composition of two KEMs using such a PRF, and prove that it's IND-CCA\text{IND-CCA}IND-CCA secure, assuming the PRF is split-key secure, and one of the underlying KEMs is IND-CCA\text{IND-CCA}IND-CCA secure.

We start with two KEMs, AAA, and BBB. The composition will be like the informal idea we saw earlier: in order to encapsulate, we use the encapsulation from each KEM, and then combine them together as a pair (cA,cB)(c_A, c_B)(cA​,cB​). When decapsulating, we end up with two keys kAk_AkA​ and kBk_BkB​. We'll use a split-key PRF to combine them, including the ciphertexts, to give us:

k←F(kA,kB,(cA,cB))k \gets F(k_A, k_B, (c_A, c_B))k←F(kA​,kB​,(cA​,cB​))

A bit more formally, given two KEMs AAA and BBB, and a function

F:A.K×B.K×(A.C×B.C)→KF : A.\bold{K} \times B.\bold{K} \times (A.\bold{C} \times B.\bold{C}) \to \bold{K}F:A.K×B.K×(A.C×B.C)→K

we can define the combined KEM A×FBA \times_F BA×F​B as follows:

Gen():‾ (skA,pkA)←A.Gen() (skB,pkB)←B.Gen() return ((skA,skB),(pkA,pkB))Encap((pkA,pkB):‾ (kA,cA)←A.Encap(pkA) (kB,cB)←B.Encap(pkB) k←F(kA,kB,(cA,cB)) return (k,(cA,cB))Decap((skA,skB),(cA,cB)):‾ kA←A.Decap(skA,cA) kB←B.Decap(skB,cB) k←F(kA,kB,(cA,cB)) return k\begin{aligned} &\underline{\text{Gen}():}\cr &\ (\text{sk}_A, \text{pk}_A) \gets \text{A.Gen}()\cr &\ (\text{sk}_B, \text{pk}_B) \gets \text{B.Gen}()\cr &\ \texttt{return } ((\text{sk}_A, \text{sk}_B), (\text{pk}_A, \text{pk}_B)) \cr \cr &\underline{\text{Encap}((\text{pk}_A, \text{pk}_B):}\cr &\ (k_A, c_A) \gets \text{A.Encap}(\text{pk}_A)\cr &\ (k_B, c_B) \gets \text{B.Encap}(\text{pk}_B)\cr &\ k \gets F(k_A, k_B, (c_A, c_B))\cr &\ \texttt{return } (k, (c_A, c_B))\cr \cr &\underline{\text{Decap}((\text{sk}_A, \text{sk}_B), (c_A, c_B)):}\cr &\ k_A \gets \text{A.Decap}(\text{sk}_A, c_A)\cr &\ k_B \gets \text{B.Decap}(\text{sk}_B, c_B)\cr &\ k \gets F(k_A, k_B, (c_A, c_B))\cr &\ \texttt{return } k\cr \end{aligned}​Gen():​ (skA​,pkA​)←A.Gen() (skB​,pkB​)←B.Gen() return ((skA​,skB​),(pkA​,pkB​))Encap((pkA​,pkB​):​ (kA​,cA​)←A.Encap(pkA​) (kB​,cB​)←B.Encap(pkB​) k←F(kA​,kB​,(cA​,cB​)) return (k,(cA​,cB​))Decap((skA​,skB​),(cA​,cB​)):​ kA​←A.Decap(skA​,cA​) kB​←B.Decap(skB​,cB​) k←F(kA​,kB​,(cA​,cB​)) return k​

In terms of encapsulation, this works in the way you'd expect for a product construction. The only real trick comes from decapsulation, where we use our function FFF to combine both keys and the ciphertexts to produce a final key.

Security Proof

It turns out that if FFF is a split-key PRF, then the security of this scheme reduces to that of either one of the KEMs.

Because our combined KEM definition is completely symmetric with respect to AAA or BBB, we prove this, without loss of generality, just by treating the case where AAA is IND-CCA\text{IND-CCA}IND-CCA secure, and show that:

IND-CCA-1(A×FB)≤2⋅IND-CCA-1(A)+2⋅SPLIT-PRF\text{IND-CCA-1}(A \times_F B) \leq 2 \cdot \text{IND-CCA-1}(A) + 2 \cdot \text{SPLIT-PRF}IND-CCA-1(A×F​B)≤2⋅IND-CCA-1(A)+2⋅SPLIT-PRF

Let's start, as we've done a few times in this post, by explicitly writing out the IND-CCA-1\text{IND-CCA-1}IND-CCA-1 game using our KEM:

IND-CCA-1b seen←∅(skA,pkA)←RA.Gen()(skB,pkB)←RB.Gen()GetPk():‾ return (pkA,pkB)(1)Challenge():‾ (kA,cA)←A.Encap(pkA) (kB,cB)←B.Encap(pkB) k0←F(kA,kB,(cA,cB)) k1←RK seen←seen∪{(cA,cB)} return (kb,(cA,cB))Decap((c^A,c^B)):‾ assert (c^A,c^B)∉seen k^A←A.Decap(skA,c^A) k^B←B.Decap(skB,c^B) if k^A=⊥∨k^B=⊥ return ⊥ return F(k^A,k^B,(c^A,c^B))\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\text{IND-CCA-1}_b$ }\cr \cr &\text{seen} \gets \emptyset\cr &(\text{sk}_A, \text{pk}_A) \xleftarrow{R} \text{A.Gen}()\cr &(\text{sk}_B, \text{pk}_B) \xleftarrow{R} \text{B.Gen}()\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{GetPk}():}\cr &\ \texttt{return } (\text{pk}_A, \text{pk}_B) \cr \cr &\underline{(1)\mathtt{Challenge}():}\cr &\ (k_A, c_A) \gets \text{A.Encap}(\text{pk}_A) \cr &\ (k_B, c_B) \gets \text{B.Encap}(\text{pk}_B) \cr &\ k_0 \gets F(k_A, k_B, (c_A, c_B))\cr &\ k_1 \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K} \cr &\ \text{seen} \gets \text{seen} \cup \{(c_A, c_B)\}\cr &\ \texttt{return } (k_b, (c_A, c_B)) \cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{Decap}((\hat{c}_A, \hat{c}_B)):}\cr &\ \texttt{assert } (\hat{c}_A, \hat{c}_B) \notin \text{seen}\cr &\ \hat{k}_A \gets \text{A.Decap}(\text{sk}_A, \hat{c}_A)\cr &\ \hat{k}_B \gets \text{B.Decap}(\text{sk}_B, \hat{c}_B)\cr &\ \texttt{if } \hat{k}_A = \bot \lor \hat{k}_B = \bot\cr &\ \quad \texttt{return } \bot\cr &\ \texttt{return } F(\hat{k}_A, \hat{k}_B, (\hat{c}_A, \hat{c}_B)) \cr \end{aligned} }​IND-CCA-1b​ ​seen←∅(skA​,pkA​)R​A.Gen()(skB​,pkB​)R​B.Gen()GetPk():​ return (pkA​,pkB​)(1)Challenge():​ (kA​,cA​)←A.Encap(pkA​) (kB​,cB​)←B.Encap(pkB​) k0​←F(kA​,kB​,(cA​,cB​)) k1​R​K seen←seen∪{(cA​,cB​)} return (kb​,(cA​,cB​))Decap((c^A​,c^B​)):​ assert (c^A​,c^B​)∈/seen k^A​←A.Decap(skA​,c^A​) k^B​←B.Decap(skB​,c^B​) if k^A​=⊥∨k^B​=⊥ return ⊥ return F(k^A​,k^B​,(c^A​,c^B​))​​

Next, we pull the usual trick of pulling out code from Challenge\texttt{Challenge}Challenge, since it only gets called a single time. We also want to change the decapsulation function to minimize the use of skA\text{sk}_AskA​, since we'll be replacing explicit calls to Decap\text{Decap}Decap with oracle calls to IND-CCA-1(A)\text{IND-CCA-1}(A)IND-CCA-1(A).

IND-CCA-1b=Γb0 (skA,pkA)←RA.Gen()(skB,pkB)←RB.Gen() (kA,cA)←A.Encap(pkA) (kB,cB)←B.Encap(pkB) k0←F(kA,kB,(cA,cB)) k1←RKGetPk():‾ return (pkA,pkB)(1)Challenge():‾ return (kb,(cA,cB))d[⋅]←⊥Decap((c^A,c^B)):‾ assert (c^A,c^B)≠(cA,cB) k^B←B.Decap(skB,c^B) if k^B=⊥ return ⊥ if c^A=cA k^A←kA else  k^A←A.Decap(skA,c^A) if k^A=⊥ return ⊥ if (c^A,c^B)∉d d[(c^A,c^B)]←F(k^A,k^B,(c^A,c^B)) return d[(c^A,c^B)]\text{IND-CCA-1}_b = \boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\Gamma^0_b$ }\cr \cr &(\text{sk}_A, \text{pk}_A) \xleftarrow{R} \text{A.Gen}()\cr &(\text{sk}_B, \text{pk}_B) \xleftarrow{R} \text{B.Gen}()\cr &\ (k_A, c_A) \gets \text{A.Encap}(\text{pk}_A) \cr &\ (k_B, c_B) \gets \text{B.Encap}(\text{pk}_B) \cr &\ k_0 \gets F(k_A, k_B, (c_A, c_B))\cr &\ k_1 \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K} \cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{GetPk}():}\cr &\ \texttt{return } (\text{pk}_A, \text{pk}_B) \cr \cr &\underline{(1)\mathtt{Challenge}():}\cr &\ \texttt{return } (k_b, (c_A, c_B)) \cr \cr &d[\cdot] \gets \bot\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{Decap}((\hat{c}_A, \hat{c}_B)):}\cr &\ \texttt{assert } (\hat{c}_A, \hat{c}_B) \neq (c_A, c_B)\cr &\ \hat{k}_B \gets \text{B.Decap}(\text{sk}_B, \hat{c}_B)\cr &\ \texttt{if } \hat{k}_B = \bot\cr &\ \quad \texttt{return } \bot\cr &\ \texttt{if } \hat{c}_A = c_A\cr &\ \quad \hat{k}_A \gets k_A\cr &\ \texttt{else }\cr &\ \quad \hat{k}_A \gets \text{A.Decap}(\text{sk}_A, \hat{c}_A)\cr &\ \quad \texttt{if } \hat{k}_A = \bot\cr &\ \quad\quad \texttt{return } \bot\cr &\ \texttt{if } (\hat{c}_A, \hat{c}_B) \notin d\cr &\ \quad d[(\hat{c}_A, \hat{c}_B)] \gets F(\hat{k}_A, \hat{k}_B, (\hat{c}_A, \hat{c}_B))\cr &\ \texttt{return } d[(\hat{c}_A, \hat{c}_B)] \cr \end{aligned} }IND-CCA-1b​=​Γb0​ ​(skA​,pkA​)R​A.Gen()(skB​,pkB​)R​B.Gen() (kA​,cA​)←A.Encap(pkA​) (kB​,cB​)←B.Encap(pkB​) k0​←F(kA​,kB​,(cA​,cB​)) k1​R​KGetPk():​ return (pkA​,pkB​)(1)Challenge():​ return (kb​,(cA​,cB​))d[⋅]←⊥Decap((c^A​,c^B​)):​ assert (c^A​,c^B​)=(cA​,cB​) k^B​←B.Decap(skB​,c^B​) if k^B​=⊥ return ⊥ if c^A​=cA​ k^A​←kA​ else  k^A​←A.Decap(skA​,c^A​) if k^A​=⊥ return ⊥ if (c^A​,c^B​)∈/d d[(c^A​,c^B​)]←F(k^A​,k^B​,(c^A​,c^B​)) return d[(c^A​,c^B​)]​​

The behavior of decapsulation is the same, we just make a few preparations for later.

First, we cache the output of the decapsulation in ddd. This is because the PRF oracle we'll use later can't be queried twice on the same input, so we'll need to use this table to avoid doing that.

Second, we check whether c^A=cA\hat{c}_A = c_Ac^A​=cA​ in order to explictly use the hardcoded kAk_AkA​. This will make extracting out the AAA KEM much easier.

Our next step is to extract out this KEM.

Γb0=Γb1 (skB,pkB)←RB.Gen() (kA,cA)←super.Challenge() (kB,cB)←B.Encap(pkB) k0←F(kA,kB,(cA,cB)) k1←RKGetPk():‾ pkA←super.GetPk() return (pkA,pkB)(1)Challenge():‾ return (kb,(cA,cB))d[⋅]←⊥Decap((c^A,c^B)):‾ assert (c^A,c^B)≠(cA,cB) k^B←B.Decap(skB,c^B) if k^B=⊥ return ⊥ if c^A=cA k^A←kA else  k^A←super.Decap(c^A) if k^A=⊥ return ⊥ if (c^A,c^B)∉d d[(c^A,c^B)]←F(k^A,k^B,(c^A,c^B)) return d[(c^A,c^B)]∘IND-CCA-10(A)\Gamma^0_b \text{IND-CCA-1}_0(A)Γb0​=​Γb1​ ​(skB​,pkB​)R​B.Gen() (kA​,cA​)←super.Challenge() (kB​,cB​)←B.Encap(pkB​) k0​←F(kA​,kB​,(cA​,cB​)) k1​R​KGetPk():​ pkA​←super.GetPk() return (pkA​,pkB​)(1)Challenge():​ return (kb​,(cA​,cB​))d[⋅]←⊥Decap((c^A​,c^B​)):​ assert (c^A​,c^B​)=(cA​,cB​) k^B​←B.Decap(skB​,c^B​) if k^B​=⊥ return ⊥ if c^A​=cA​ k^A​←kA​ else  k^A​←super.Decap(c^A​) if k^A​=⊥ return ⊥ if (c^A​,c^B​)∈/d d[(c^A​,c^B​)]←F(k^A​,k^B​,(c^A​,c^B​)) return d[(c^A​,c^B​)]​​∘IND-CCA-10​(A)

With this game, we've extracted out the AAA KEM completely. One key thing which enabled us to do this was checking that c^A=cA\hat{c}_A = c_Ac^A​=cA​ ourselves, to avoid hitting the assertion inside of AAA's Decap\texttt{Decap}Decap oracle.

Naturally, we'll be able to make the jump from IND-CCA-10(A)\text{IND-CCA-1}_0(A)IND-CCA-10​(A) to IND-CCA-11(A)\text{IND-CCA-1}_1(A)IND-CCA-11​(A), but that won't be enough to complete our proof. We still need to make use of our PRF assumption.

To that effect, let's write a game which explicitly captures what happens after making the switch to an ideal KEM:

Γb1∘IND-CCA-11(A)=Γb2 (skB,pkB)←RB.Gen() (⋅,cB)←A.Encap(pkA) kA←RA.K (kB,cB)←B.Encap(pkB) k0←F(kA,kB,(cA,cB)) k1←RKGetPk():‾ pkA←super.GetPk() return (pkA,pkB)(1)Challenge():‾ return (kb,(cA,cB))d[⋅]←⊥Decap((c^A,c^B)):‾ assert (c^A,c^B)≠(cA,cB) k^B←B.Decap(skB,c^B) if k^B=⊥ return ⊥ if c^A=cA if (c^A,c^B)∉d d[(c^A,c^B)]←F(kA,k^B,(c^A,c^B)) return d[(c^A,c^B)] else  k^A←super.Decap(c^A) if k^A=⊥ return ⊥ return F(k^A,k^B,(c^A,c^B))\Gamma^1_b At the start of the game, we can ignore whatever key we get from AAA's encapsulation, and instead use a random kAk_AkA​.

At the end of the game, in decapsulation, we've shifted things around to make how the PRF is queried more clear. In one branch, we query the PRF using that initial kAk_AkA​ key, and so we want to make sure to cache results. In the other branch, we use an unrelated key, and so we don't care.

Our next trick is going to be to replace calls to F(kA,…)F(k_A, \ldots)F(kA​,…) with oracle queries to the SPLIT-PRF\text{SPLIT-PRF}SPLIT-PRF game.

Γb2=Γb3 (skB,pkB)←RB.Gen() (⋅,cB)←A.Encap(pkA) (kB,cB)←B.Encap(pkB) k0←super.QueryF(kB,(cA,cB)) k1←RKGetPk():‾ pkA←super.GetPk() return (pkA,pkB)(1)Challenge():‾ return (kb,(cA,cB))d[⋅]←⊥Decap((c^A,c^B)):‾ assert (c^A,c^B)≠(cA,cB) k^B←B.Decap(skB,c^B) if k^B=⊥ return ⊥ if c^A=cA if (c^A,c^B)∉d d[(c^A,c^B)]←super.QueryF(k^B,(c^A,c^B)) return d[(c^A,c^B)] else  k^A←super.Decap(c^A) if k^A=⊥ return ⊥ return F(k^A,k^B,(c^A,c^B))∘SPLIT-PRF0\Gamma^2_b = \boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\Gamma^3_b$ }\cr \cr &(\text{sk}_B, \text{pk}_B) \xleftarrow{R} \text{B.Gen}()\cr &\ (\cdot, c_B) \gets \text{A.Encap}(\text{pk}_A) \cr &\ (k_B, \texttt{super.GetPk}()\cr &\ \texttt{return } (\text{pk}_A, \text{pk}_B) \cr \cr &\underline{(1)\mathtt{Challenge}():}\cr &\ \texttt{return } (k_b, (c_A, c_B)) \cr \cr &d[\cdot] \gets \bot\cr \cr &\underline{\mathtt{Decap}((\hat{c}_A, \hat{c}_B)):}\cr &\ \texttt{assert } (\hat{c}_A, \hat{c}_B) \neq (c_A, c_B)\cr &\ \hat{k}_B \gets \text{B.Decap}(\text{sk}_B, \hat{c}_B)\cr &\ \texttt{if } \hat{k}_B = \bot\cr &\ \quad \texttt{return } \bot\cr &\ \texttt{if } \hat{c}_A = c_A\cr &\ \quad\texttt{if } (\hat{c}_A, \hat{c}_B) \notin d\cr &\ \quad\quad d[(\hat{c}_A, \hat{c}_B)] \gets \quad \texttt{if } \hat{k}_A = \bot\cr &\ \quad\quad\texttt{return } \bot \cr &\ \quad \texttt{return } F(\hat{k}_A, \hat{k}_B, (\hat{c}_A, \hat{c}_B))\cr \end{aligned} } \circ \text{SPLIT-PRF}_0Γb2​=​Γb3​ ​(skB​,pkB​)R​B.Gen() (⋅,cB​)←A.Encap(pkA​) (kB​,cB​)←B.Encap(pkB​) k0​←super.QueryF(kB​,(cA​,cB​)) k1​R​KGetPk():​ pkA​←super.GetPk() return (pkA​,pkB​)(1)Challenge():​ return (kb​,(cA​,cB​))d[⋅]←⊥Decap((c^A​,c^B​)):​ assert (c^A​,c^B​)=(cA​,cB​) k^B​←B.Decap(skB​,c^B​) if k^B​=⊥ return ⊥ if c^A​=cA​ if (c^A​,c^B​)∈/d d[(c^A​,c^B​)]←super.QueryF(k^B​,(c^A​,c^B​)) return d[(c^A​,c^B​)] else  k^A​←super.Decap(c^A​) if k^A​=⊥ return ⊥ return F(k^A​,k^B​,(c^A​,c^B​))​​∘SPLIT-PRF0​

One interesting thing is that we keep calls to the actual function FFF, we just use the oracle queries for when the key kAk_AkA​ was used before.

Now, the next question is: what happens when our PRF is perfect? Well, we get the following situation:

Γb3∘SPLIT-PRF1=Γb4 (skB,pkB)←RB.Gen() (⋅,cB)←A.Encap(pkA) (kB,cB)←B.Encap(pkB) k0←RK k1←RK…\Gamma^3_b \circ \text{SPLIT-PRF}_1 = \boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\Gamma^4_b$ }\cr \cr &(\text{sk}_B, \text{pk}_B) \xleftarrow{R} \text{B.Gen}()\cr &\ (\cdot, c_B) \gets \text{A.Encap}(\text{pk}_A) \cr &\ (k_B, c_B) \gets \text{B.Encap}(\text{pk}_B) \cr &\ k_0 \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K} \cr &\ k_1 \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K} \cr &\ldots\cr \end{aligned} }Γb3​∘SPLIT-PRF1​=​Γb4​ ​(skB​,pkB​)R​B.Gen() (⋅,cB​)←A.Encap(pkA​) (kB​,cB​)←B.Encap(pkB​) k0​R​K k1​R​K…​​

The rest of the game doesn't matter. The important part is that now there's no difference between k0k_0k0​ and k1k_1k1​, and so we have Γ04=Γ14\Gamma^4_0 = \Gamma^4_1Γ04​=Γ14​. Now, we can do the walk backwards, chaining everything together to get our result:

IND-CCA-10=Γ00=Γ01∘IND-CCA-10(A)≈ϵ1Γ01∘IND-CCA-11(A)=Γ02=Γ03∘SPLIT-PRF0≈ϵ2Γ03∘SPLIT-PRF1=Γ04=Γ14=Γ13∘SPLIT-PRF1≈ϵ2Γ13∘SPLIT-PRF0=Γ12=Γ11∘IND-CCA-11(A)≈ϵ1Γ11∘IND-CCA-10(A)=Γ10=IND-CCA-11\begin{aligned} \text{IND-CCA-1}_0 &= \Gamma^0_0\cr &= \Gamma^1_0 \circ \text{IND-CCA-1}_0(A)\cr &\stackrel{\epsilon_1}{\approx} \Gamma^1_0 \circ \text{IND-CCA-1}_1(A)\cr &= \Gamma^2_0\cr &= \Gamma^3_0 \circ \text{SPLIT-PRF}_0\cr &\stackrel{\epsilon_2}{\approx} \Gamma^3_0 \circ \text{SPLIT-PRF}_1\cr &= \Gamma^4_0\cr &= \Gamma^4_1\cr &= \Gamma^3_1 \circ \text{SPLIT-PRF}_1\cr &\stackrel{\epsilon_2}{\approx} \Gamma^3_1 \circ \text{SPLIT-PRF}_0\cr &= \Gamma^2_1\cr &= \Gamma^1_1 \circ \text{IND-CCA-1}_1(A)\cr &\stackrel{\epsilon_1}{\approx} \Gamma^1_1 \circ \text{IND-CCA-1}_0(A)\cr &= \Gamma^0_1\cr &= \text{IND-CCA-1}_1\cr \end{aligned}IND-CCA-10​​=Γ00​=Γ01​∘IND-CCA-10​(A)≈ϵ1​Γ01​∘IND-CCA-11​(A)=Γ02​=Γ03​∘SPLIT-PRF0​≈ϵ2​Γ03​∘SPLIT-PRF1​=Γ04​=Γ14​=Γ13​∘SPLIT-PRF1​≈ϵ2​Γ13​∘SPLIT-PRF0​=Γ12​=Γ11​∘IND-CCA-11​(A)≈ϵ1​Γ11​∘IND-CCA-10​(A)=Γ10​=IND-CCA-11​​

□\square□

Constructing Split-Key PRFs

In the KEM combiner paper [^[GHP18]], they present many examples of split-key PRFs. As an illustration, I'll choose one of the simplest ones, which can be proven secure even without random oracles. I'd recommend checking out the papers for other more efficient constructions.

Xoring Two PRFs

One simple construction involves combining two PRFs F0F_0F0​ and F1F_1F1​ together:

F(k0,k1,x):=F0(k0,x)⊕F1(k1,x)F(k_0, k_1, x) := F_0(k_0, x) \oplus F_1(k_1, x)F(k0​,k1​,x):=F0​(k0​,x)⊕F1​(k1​,x)

This PRF is split-key because even if you can influence one of the keys, the other side looks completely random, and thus so is the final result. Let's prove this a bit more formally.

Without loss of generality, we can simply prove that it's split key for the first key, k0k_0k0​, since the function is symmetric.

SPLIT-PRF(0)≤PRF(F0)\text{SPLIT-PRF}(0) \leq \text{PRF}(F_0)SPLIT-PRF(0)≤PRF(F0​)

The high level proof idea is that what happens with F1F_1F1​ can't affect the outcome, because F0F_0F0​ being a PRF is enough to guarantee that the output is random. In our split-key game, we'll easily be able to

First, explicitly write the split-key game:

SPLIT-PRF0  k_0←RK0 seen←∅QueryF(k1,x):‾ assert x∉seen y←F(k0,x)⊕F(k1,x) return y\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\text{SPLIT-PRF}_0$ }\cr \cr &\ k\_0 \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}_0\cr &\ \text{seen} \gets \emptyset\cr \cr &\underline{\texttt{QueryF}(k_1, x):}\cr &\ \texttt{assert } x \notin \text{seen}\cr &\ y \gets F(k_0, x) \oplus F(k_1, x)\cr &\ \texttt{return } y \end{aligned} }​SPLIT-PRF0​ ​ k_0R​K0​ seen←∅QueryF(k1​,x):​ assert x∈/seen y←F(k0​,x)⊕F(k1​,x) return y​​

Next, extract out F0F_0F0​:

SPLIT-PRF0=Γ QueryF(k1,x):‾ y←super.QueryF(x)⊕F(k1,x) return y∘PRF0  k←RK0 seen←∅QueryF(k1,x):‾ assert x∉seen y←F(k0,x) return y\text{SPLIT-PRF}_0 = \boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\Gamma$ }\cr \cr &\underline{\texttt{QueryF}(k_1, x):}\cr &\ y \gets \texttt{super.QueryF}(x) \oplus F(k_1, x)\cr &\ \texttt{return } y \end{aligned} } \circ \boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\text{PRF}_0$ }\cr \cr &\ k \xleftarrow{R} \bold{K}_0\cr &\ \text{seen} \gets \emptyset\cr \cr &\underline{\texttt{QueryF}(k_1, x):}\cr &\ \texttt{assert } x \notin \text{seen}\cr &\ y \gets F(k_0, x) \cr &\ \texttt{return } y \end{aligned} }SPLIT-PRF0​=​Γ ​QueryF(k1​,x):​ y←super.QueryF(x)⊕F(k1​,x) return y​​∘​PRF0​ ​ kR​K0​ seen←∅QueryF(k1​,x):​ assert x∈/seen y←F(k0​,x) return y​​

Next, notice that if we switch to PRF1\text{PRF}_1PRF1​, then the output of Γ\GammaΓ becomes completely random:

Γ QueryF(k1,x):‾ y←super.QueryF(x)⊕F(k1,x) return y∘PRF1  seen←∅QueryF(k1,x):‾ assert x∉seen y←RY return y=SPLIT-PRF1 seen←∅QueryF(k1,x):‾ assert x∉seen y←RY return y\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\Gamma$ }\cr \cr &\underline{\texttt{QueryF}(k_1, x):}\cr &\ y \gets \texttt{super.QueryF}(x) \oplus F(k_1, x)\cr &\ \texttt{return } y \end{aligned} } \circ \boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\text{PRF}_1$ }\cr \cr &\ \text{seen} \gets \emptyset\cr \cr &\underline{\texttt{QueryF}(k_1, x):}\cr &\ \texttt{assert } x \notin \text{seen}\cr &\ y \xleftarrow{R} \bold{Y}\cr &\ \texttt{return } y \end{aligned} } = \boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\colorbox{#FBCFE8}{\large $\text{SPLIT-PRF}_1$ }\cr \cr &\text{seen} \gets \emptyset\cr \cr &\underline{\texttt{QueryF}(k_1, x):}\cr &\ \texttt{assert } x \notin \text{seen}\cr &\ y \xleftarrow{R} \bold{Y}\cr &\ \texttt{return } y \end{aligned} }​Γ ​QueryF(k1​,x):​ y←super.QueryF(x)⊕F(k1​,x) return y​​∘​PRF1​ ​ seen←∅QueryF(k1​,x):​ assert x∈/seen yR​Y return y​​=​SPLIT-PRF1​ ​seen←∅QueryF(k1​,x):​ assert x∈/seen yR​Y return y​​

This is because xoring any value with a (uniformly) random value returns another random value. Thus, xoring F(k1,x)F(k_1, x)F(k1​,x) with a random yyy gives us a random result.

To summarize, we have:

SPLIT-PRF0=Γ∘PRF0≈ϵ1Γ∘PRF1=SPLIT-PRF1\text{SPLIT-PRF}_0 = \Gamma \circ \text{PRF}_0 \stackrel{\epsilon_1}{\approx} \Gamma \circ \text{PRF}_1 = \text{SPLIT-PRF}_1SPLIT-PRF0​=Γ∘PRF0​≈ϵ1​Γ∘PRF1​=SPLIT-PRF1​

which concludes our proof.

□\square□

Other Methods

The kem combiner paper [^GHP18] also provides various other methods for creating split-key PRFs.

One method is to do F(kA,cA)⊕F(kB,cB)F(k_A, c_A) \oplus F(k_B, c_B)F(kA​,cA​)⊕F(kB​,cB​), including only one of the ciphertexts.

Another method, which requires the random oracle model, is to do: H(kA⊕kB,cA,cB){H(k_A \oplus k_B, c_A, c_B)}H(kA​⊕kB​,cA​,cB​).

And this is just a small sample; I really recommend checking out the paper if you want to know more; it's a very well written paper!

Conclusion

While there weren't that many topics covered in thist post, I felt that stopping it here made for a hefty post already, especially with the focus on proofs. I think state-separable proofs are quite fun to write, and hopefully they were enjoyable to read as well. A secret about this post is that KEMs are really just an excuse to write more state-separable proofs, since that's what motivated me to write about the topic.

There's still a lot more interesting things to say about KEMs though. One notion I didn't touch on at all here is that of authenticated KEMs, where you also want to authenticate the sender in some way. Neil Madden wrote a post on this topic as well, and you might want to check out [^ABHKLR20], which analyzes the HPKE standard for authenticated KEMs, outlining various notions of security for this construction.

Another thing that would be neat to go over is the notion of deniable authenticated KEMs, wherein it's possible to forge ciphertexts which claim to have been sent by another person to yourself. This makes it so that KEM ciphertexts can't be used as evidence of communication between two parties.

This also butts heads against the notion of insider security, which Yolan Romailler brought to my attention on twitter. See also his blog post touching on ephemeral keys and insider security in key exchanges.
